questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?

choices.text: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
Chlorine acts best when the  pH of water is around seven
It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity

questions.solution:
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of the hypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH  around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective form of disinfection.

Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water.

Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses.

Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: You treat a patient suffering from Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma with IV cyclophosphamide. The drug is present in a vial in powdered form. The drug is to be given as IV infusion after restitution with normal saline. After the infusion, you decide to discard the waste. Which of the following is true about disposal?

choices.text: The glass vial is to be discarded in puncture proof blue box
Mask worn by you is considered general waste
Discard the plastic saline bottle in non-chlorinated yellow plastic bag
Unused drug to be discarded in cytotoxic labelled white bag

questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide is a cytotoxic drug. All cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated by it (including glass vials, ampoules, saline bottles) should be collected in yellow-colored non-chlorinated plastic bags labeled as cytotoxic hazard.

Option B: Mask and gowns (biochemical waste) which are reusable should be discarded in yellow-colored non-chlorinated plastic bags.

questions.text: You are performing a routine pap smear on a 30-year-old woman in the gynecology OPD. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test for carcinoma cervix and is an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment are the components of secondary prevention. Some of the examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case.

These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good indicator of efficacy of health programs?
questions.solution:
Incidence is a good indicator of the efficacy of health services and programs.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: In a school of 100 children, a child developed measles. Four days later, 3 of her classmates developed measles. What do these intervening four days correspond to?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the first child is the primary case and her classmates are the secondary cases. Hence, the interval between them developing the disease i.e., the intervening four days, is called the serial interval.

The time interval between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called serial interval.

By collecting information about a whole series of such disease onsets, the distribution of the secondary cases can be made. From this information, an approximation of the incubation period can be done.

Lead time/lead interval refers to the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Incubatory interval/ incubation period refers to the time period between invasion of a pathogen to appearance of the first sign or symptom.

Latent interval/ latent period refers to the period between disease initiation to detection of the disease. It is usually used for non-infectious diseases and is equivalent to the incubation period. 

Note :

  • Primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.  
  • Secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case.
  • Index case is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.

questions.text: In which of the following diseases should active and passive immunisation not be done together?
questions.solution:
Active and passive immunization should not be done together for measles as the vaccine used is a live vaccine.

Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks.

Note: In the case of measles alone, the recommended interval between administration of Measles immunoglobulins and Live measles vaccine is about 6 months in a non-immunocompromised individual and 8 months in an immunocompromised individual.

questions.text: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination is she eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.

The 17D vaccine for yellow fever is given subcutaneously. Unvaccinated people are required to remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

questions.text: Which of the following measures for controlling malaria is the Urban Malaria Scheme mainly based on?
questions.solution:
The Urban Malaria Scheme is mainly based on anti-larval measures for controlling malaria. In Urban Malaria Scheme, urban areas with a population of >50,000 and a slide positivity rate of ≥5% are included. 

The vector in urban areas breeds in man-made containers. Therefore, anti-larval measures such as larvivorous fish and larvicides are used to control breeding as the primary method of vector control.

In rural areas, anti-adult measures, such as Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) is the primary method of vector control.

questions.text: According to the revised strategy for the eradication of kala-azar, which of the following drugs would you use across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection?
questions.solution:
A single dose of intravenous treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is used across all age groups in order to reduce the human reservoir of infection. WHO will supply this drug free of cost. 

Drugs for Kala Azar:

  • Single-dose intravenous liposomal amphotericin B for all age groups and for pregnant and HIV co-infected patients.
  • Miltefosine- an oral drug, once daily for 28 days. Contraindicated during pregnancy, lactation, and in women who refuse contraception.
  • Combination of miltefosine capsules with paromomycin i.m, for 10 days. Contraindications are the same as miltefosine.
  • The drug of choice for Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is miltefosine 100mg orally per day for 12 weeks.

Ivermectin is used for lymphatic filariasis.

Provide LED bulbs in every household

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (stage 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: While conducting a demographic study, you need to calculate the total dependency ratio of the study population. Which of the following will you include in the numerator while calculating this?

choices.text: Population under 10 years and above 60 years
Population under 15 years and above 60 years
Population under 10 years and above 65 years
Population under 15 years and above 65 years

questions.solution:
Population under 15 years and above 65 years are part of the numerator used to calculate the total dependency ratio. This is because this population is considered the dependant population.

The dependant population includes children below 15 years of age and adults above 65 years of age. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 - 65 years. It is also called the societal dependency ratio. It can also be divided into the young-age and old-age dependency ratios.

Note: As of mid-year 2020, the dependency ratio of India is 48.7%.

questions.text: What is the definition of the net reproduction rate?

choices.text: No. of children that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of girls  that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of female children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate

questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate.

India is aiming for an NRR of 1 as it is equivalent to the two-child norm.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: As part of the National family planning program, you are conducting a study in a village to gather data on the efficacy of a new contraceptive. 20 out of 100 women became pregnant in the village despite using this contraceptive for a period of 2 years continuously. What is the pearl index of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 10 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 20. The total months of exposure are 24 months for each woman.

Hence, the total months of exposure for 100 women are 24 x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/ Total months of exposure 

Hence, pearl index= 20 x 1200/2400 = 10 per HWY

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: What is the best indicator of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 50 per 1000 live births.

Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year

In this population, there were 4000 live births (no. of total births - no. of stillbirths).

NMR = (50+150) x 1000/4000 = 100/2 = 50

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about rapid sand filters?

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity or pressure type

questions.solution:
Frequent washing of the filter bed is required in rapid sand filters. This is done by backwashing.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

questions.text: You assign a male health worker at a sub-centre with the task of chlorinating public water resources. What is the minimum concentration of free residual chlorine that should be maintained for effective chlorination?

choices.text: 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour
0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour
0.8 mg/litre for a contact period of ½ hour

questions.solution:
The minimum recommended concentration of free residual chlorine for routine chlorination is 0.5 mg/litre for a contact period of 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: What is the mechanical system of ventilation which employs only centrifugal fans that create positive pressure inside a space by blowing fresh air into it called?
questions.solution:
The mechanical system of ventilation that employs only centrifugal fans is plenum ventilation.

Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:

Natural ventilation includes:

  • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
  • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action
  • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings
  • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.

The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible.

Mechanical ventilation includes:

  • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
  • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
  • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
  • Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.

questions.text: A middle-aged sandblasting factory worker presents with hemoptysis and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Which of the following occupational diseases is associated with an increased risk of developing this condition?
questions.solution:
Silicosis is associated with an increased risk of developing tuberculosis.

Patients with silicosis are more prone to develop tuberculosis, a condition called silico-tuberculosis. This is because silica causes dysfunction of the alveolar macrophages. Patients are also at greater risk of atypical mycobacteria, and fungal infections. Due to this increased risk of tuberculosis, the recommended treatment of latent tuberculosis in silicosis patients is longer.

Silicosis is a form of pneumoconiosis which is a cause of permanent disability and mortality. It occurs in people working in sandblasting, pottery, and ceramics industry, mining, and construction work. It occurs due to the inhalation of silica dust. The patient presents with cough, exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. 

In simple silicosis, the chest X-ray shows small rounded opacities in the upper lobes, and there is no impairment in lung function. When there is progressive nodular fibrosis, irregular masses >1 cm are seen, referred to as complicated silicosis. When these masses enlarge further, it is called progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) and is associated with significant impairment of lung function.

Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes and crazy paving pattern may be seen on HRCT.

As there is no effective treatment for this condition, prevention should be done by rigorous dusting measures and regular examination of the workers. Silicosis is categorized as a notifiable disease under the Factories Act, 1948. 

Other options:

Option A: Asbestosis is a form of pneumoconiosis occurring in asbestos industry workers mainly involving the basal lobes. It can be associated with mesothelioma, a form of lung malignancy on long-term exposure.

Option C: Anthracosis is also known as coal worker's pneumonia and occurs in people working with coal dust. It tends to cause pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option D: Siderosis occurs due to prolonged exposure to iron deposits.

questions.text: There are 50 patients admitted in a ward of your medical college. Here 20 are girls and 30 are boys. Out of this, 10 girls and 20 boys require surgery. What is the probability that a randomly selected boy and girl both require surgery?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the probability that a randomly selected boy and girl both require surgery is 1/3.

First, we have to calculate the probability of picking the boys requiring surgery and the girls requiring surgery separately. These are mutually exclusive events.

In this scenario, the probability of correctly picking a girl requiring surgery is p(A)=10/20= 1/2

The probability of correctly picking a boy requiring surgery is p(B)=20/30= 2/3

Next, we apply the multiplication rule of probability.

The probability of picking boys and girls that require surgery,

p(A and B)= p(A) x p(B)= ½ x ⅔ = 2/6= 1/3.

  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

questions.text: Which of the following can have more than one value?
questions.solution:
The mode of a given sample can have more than one value. It is the most frequently occurring value in a distribution. 

For example, in the sample [1, 3, 6, 6, 6, 6, 7, 7, 12, 12, 17], the most repeated value i.e., the mode is 6.

For the list of data [1, 1, 2, 4, 4], the mode is 1 and 4. Therefore, the mode is not unique. This dataset may be said to be bimodal, while a set with more than two modes may be described as multimodal.

Median can have only one value, obtained by arranging values in order and then picking out the central value. In a sample with an even number of elements, median is obtained by taking the average of the middle 2 elements.

Mean can only have a single value. The harmonic mean is the reciprocal of the arithmetic mean of the reciprocals of the data values. The geometric mean is obtained by taking the arithmetic mean of values on a logarithmic scale.

Related Pearl: The Mode in Biostatistics

  • The mode is most frequently occurring observed value in a distribution.
  • A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.
  • If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.
  • If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.
  • The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.
  • Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.

  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:

questions.text: A randomized trial comparing the efficacy of two drugs showed a difference between the two with a p value of <0.005. In reality, both drugs do not differ at all. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, let’s take the null hypothesis as the two drugs being the same, which the questions states, is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will then be that both drugs are different.
  • The questions states that p value was found to be < 0.005, which is statistically significant and so the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But we already know that the null hypothesis is true and we are forced to accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false.
  • This is a type I error or alpha error.
  • When an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: In which of the following sampling techniques is design effect used?
questions.solution:
The design effect is used in cluster sampling to allow for design structure and correlation between clusters.

The design effect (DEFF) is used to decide the sample size needed for cluster sampling. This is done by calculating the difference in sampling variability to the variability expected with simple random sampling (SRS).

It can more simply be stated as the actual sample size divided by the effective sample size (what you would expect if you were using SRS). For example, let’s say you were using cluster sampling. A DEFF of 2 means the variance is twice as large as you would expect with SRS. It also means that if you used cluster sampling, you’d have to use twice the sample size.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections.

Male parasite burrows into the epidermis
The entire life cycle takes about 15 days

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive of scabies. The given image depicts an itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The incorrect statement is that the male parasite burrows into the epidermis.

The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow. A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow. The larval stage, which emerges from the eggs, has 3 pairs of legs. After the larvae moult, the resulting nymphs have 4 pairs of legs.

The life cycle has 4 stages- egg, larva, nymph, and adult. It takes about 10-15 days to progress from egg to adult. However, the adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasites in the epidermis. Clinical features include itching severe at night, superficial burrows in the affected site, and secondary infection of the lesions leading to crusted papules and pustules. Multiple members of a household may be affected, hence simultaneous treatment of all the household contacts is essential.

 

The diagnosis is made by visualizing the parasite in skin debris under a microscope. Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following reflects the diagnostic power of a screening test?
questions.solution:
The predictive accuracy of a screening test reflects its performance and diagnostic power.

Predictive accuracy is given by:

  • Positive predictive value (PPV): the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having the disease.
  • Negative predictive value (NPV): the probability of a person with a negative test, definitely not having the disease.

Sensitivity is the ability of a screening test to detect true positive out of total disease.

Specificity is the ability of a screening test to detect true negative out of total nondiseased.

The reliability of a test implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: Under the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment, NGO eye hospitals are considered as:
questions.solution:
NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level centres under the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI).

Levels of eye care centres according to NPCBVI:

  • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centres, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, and link workers.
  • Secondary level: District hospitals and NGO eye hospitals.
  • Tertiary level: Regional institutes of ophthalmology and medical colleges.

The goal of NPCBVI is to reduce the prevalence of blindness to 0.25% by 2025.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to measure the output of the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment?

choices.text: Number of cases of refractory errors corrected
Number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration
Number of cases of childhood blindness detected and cured
Prevalence of blindness reduced by 0.5% per year

questions.solution:
The measure of the output of the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment (NPCBVI) is indicated by the number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration. 

The most common cause of low vision in India is cataract (low vision is visual acuity <6/18- 6/60).
